paper_id: Interannual dynamics of available potassium in a long-term fertilization experiment

description_errors: Misinterpretation of 'agrotechnics' in quality control section.
clarifications_needed: Refine description of non-regular sampling years to accurately reflect the paper's statement that sampling year did not consistently correspond to the same year of crop rotation.

missing_data_identified: Specific ANOVA statistics (SS, df, F, P-values) for factors influencing available K variability were not fully captured in the initial extraction's 'values' array, only in the 'measurement_context'.

terminology_issues: Minor imprecision in describing the non-regular sampling years' correspondence to crop rotation years.
precision_improvements: Rephrase the description of non-regular sampling years for clarity and accuracy.

high_priority_corrections.description: The original extraction incorrectly listed 'Careful agrotechnics to minimize soil translocation between plots' under 'quality_control'. The paper actually mentions 'insufficient agrotechnics' as a source of variability/limitation.
high_priority_corrections.impact_on_interpretation: Misrepresents a limitation as a quality control measure, potentially overstating experimental rigor.

medium_priority_improvements.description: The description of non-regular sampling years (1988, 1995, 2007) implies they corresponded to specific crop rotation years, whereas the paper states they 'did not correspond to the same year of crop rotation'.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Enhances precision and avoids misinterpretation of the sampling strategy for time trend analysis.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Rephrase the 'monitoring_timeline' entry for these years to accurately reflect the paper's statement.

data_enrichment_opportunities.additional_data_source: Text describing ANOVA results for available K variability.
data_enrichment_opportunities.potential_value: Provides more complete statistical context (SS, df, F, P-values) for the reported percentages of variability explained by different factors.
data_enrichment_opportunities.extraction_approach: Integrate the specific ANOVA statistics into the 'measurement_context' of the relevant primary measurement.

paper_metadata.title: Interannual dynamics of available potassium in a long-term fertilization experiment
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Interannual dynamics of plant-available potassium (K) in long-term fertilization experiments, its relationship to K balance and crop rotation, and implications for long-term trend analysis.

research_methodology.experimental_design: Polyfactorial field experiments established in 1980, using a central scheme of the second order design in incomplete blocks (Cochran and Cox, 1957). Each site had four fields, each with 56 plots (5 × 12 m) in 4 rows. Six independent factors were tested at five levels (minimum, lower, medium, higher, excess/zero). The majority of treatments were replicated four times across fields.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annually after harvest (except 2nd year of alfalfa/clover) for soil samples; plant material analyzed after each harvest. Soil sampling was reduced after 1989, with some plots sampled non-regularly.
monitoring_timeline: 1980-1992: Data used for K balance and available K dynamics within crop rotation (specifically for Hněvčeves)
1983, 1991, 1999, 2007: Specific sampling years for some treatments for time trend analysis (consistently the 2nd year of crop rotation)

1988, 1995, 2007: Specific sampling years for other treatments for time trend analysis, where the sampling year did not consistently correspond to the same year of crop rotation (e.g., sampled in the 7th, 6th, and 2nd year of crop rotation respectively for these specific years).

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Czech Republic, representing different pedo- and climasequences of arable soils.
site_characteristics: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess, loam texture, 265m altitude, 8.1°C avg annual temp, 597mm avg annual precip, initial pH 6.4, 1.0% organic carbon, 73 mg/kg available P, 119 mg/kg available K.

Humpolec: Haplic Cambisol on paragneiss, sandy loam texture, 525m altitude, 6.6°C avg annual temp, 667mm avg annual precip, initial pH 6.1, 1.7% organic carbon, 27 mg/kg available P, 212 mg/kg available K.

Pernolec: Cambisol on orthogneiss, sandy loam-loam texture, 530m altitude, 7.1°C avg annual temp, 559mm avg annual precip, initial pH 6.0, 1.1% organic carbon, 71 mg/kg available P, 185 mg/kg available K.

Kostelec n. Orlicí: Haplic Luvisol on loess, sandy loam texture, 290m altitude, 8.1°C avg annual temp, 696mm avg annual precip, initial pH 6.3, 1.1% organic carbon, 62 mg/kg available P, 119 mg/kg available K.
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Sites selected to represent different pedo- and climasequences of arable soils in the Czech Republic.

sample_design.replication_levels: 10 replications for medium level treatment within each field for variability calculation; majority of other treatments replicated four times across fields.
sample_design.randomization_approach: Central scheme of the second order design in incomplete blocks (Cochran and Cox, 1957).
controls_and_treatments: Control (all factors at zero level, i.e., 'not treated')
Treatments with different combinations of 'higher' and 'lower' levels of factors
Treatments with all factors at medium level and one factor at 'zero' or 'excess' level
Treatments with all factors at medium level (10 plots)
sample_design.statistical_power: Sufficient statistical evaluation for medium K application rate due to 10 replications.

measurement_protocols: Soil sampling: Plough horizon (0-20 cm depth) after harvest, 5-8 subsamples per plot.
Soil analysis: Soil reaction (pH in 1M KCl), organic carbon content (C_ox), total nitrogen, available nutrients (P, K, Ca, Mg).
Plant analysis: Total content of N, P, K, Ca, Mg after wet combustion.

Available K determination: Formerly ammonium acetate/oxalate extraction (Schachtschabel, Hraško et al. 1962), replaced by Mehlich II/III extraction. Data transformed back to Schachtschabel using empirical equations: K_Sch = 0.8187 × K_MII + 3.94; K_Sch = 0.712 × K_MIII + 9.96 (derived from Trávník 2008 data).
instrumentation: Not specified beyond analytical methods (e.g., pH meter, spectrophotometer, etc.).
quality_control: Data transformation equations for K determination based on large number of soil samples and published data (Trávník 2008).

detection_limits.available_k: Not specified, but values as low as 48 mg K/kg are reported.

analytical_precision.available_k_variability: Reported as ± 20 mg K/kg in other trials (Merbach and Deubel 2007), suggesting similar variability in this study contributing to residual unexplained variability.

analysis_methods: ANOVA (Main effects ANOVA for factors influencing available K variability)
Regression analysis (linear regression for time trends)
Calculation of means, standard deviations, and ranges.
statistical_approach.significance_testing: Statistically significant differences indicated by different letters (P < 0.05) for available K averages. Significance levels (P-values) reported for ANOVA factors and correlations.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Standard deviations and max-min ranges are shown for available K dynamics. Standard deviations are provided for K balance.
statistical_approach.model_validation: Not explicitly stated, but K balance calculations are compared with literature data.

primary_measurements.parameter: Available K content (medium K application rate)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Mean for whole 8-year crop rotation cycle at Hněvčeves, 1980-1992 data. Lowest content 88 mg K/kg (2nd year), 93 mg K/kg (3rd year), 125 mg K/kg (4th year), 130 mg K/kg (5th year), 149 mg K/kg (7th year), 116 mg K/kg (8th year).
Annual K input required to achieve zero K balance.

primary_measurements.parameter: K utilization from mineral fertilizer (combination C)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average utilization of K from mineral fertilizer (K muriate) at low application rates.

primary_measurements.parameter: K utilization from farmyard manure (combination B)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average utilization of K from farmyard manure at low application rates.

primary_measurements.parameter: K utilization from both forms (combinations G, H, I)
Available K variability explained by factors (Hněvčeves, 1980-1992)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Main effects ANOVA results for available K contents (153 kg K/ha application rate): Crop factor explained 34% (SS=74575, df=6, F=37.4, P<0.001); Weather factor explained 3% (SS=7257, df=10, F=2.2, P=0.019); Field factor explained 3% (SS=7586, df=3, F=7.6, P<0.001); Residual unexplained variability was 42% (SS=92432, df=278). All factors combined explained 58% of data variability.

primary_measurements.parameter: Available K content in non-fertilized plots (Hněvčeves)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Initial content 119 mg K/kg. Decreased to 65 mg K/kg in 2007. Stayed at 48-65 mg K/kg during the last 20 years with an annual balance of -122 kg K/ha.

primary_measurements.parameter: K release from soil sources (non-fertilized plots)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Estimated annual release from soil sources other than available K, based on a conversion of 1 mg/kg K = 2.5 kg K/ha (assuming 1.3 Mg/m^3 bulk density and 25 cm plough layer thickness).

primary_measurements.parameter: Slopes of available K time trends (Hněvčeves, field 3)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Calculated from 4 time points (1983/1991/1999/2007 or adjusted 1988/1995/2007). Range from -0.39 to 2.22 mg K/kg/year. Highest slopes (H, J) correspond to >2 mg K/kg/year increase (ca 1.5% of available K content).

variables: Slope of available K time trends
Slope of available K time trends

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Periodic fluctuations induced by crop rotation, with statistically significant differences between years.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Two-peak character within the 8-year crop rotation cycle, with peaks after silage maize (4th year) and sugar beet (7th year), and minimums after alfalfa (1st-2nd years).

comparative_results.practical_significance: K balance ranges from -122 kg K/ha/year (control) to +58 kg K/ha/year (excess K input). Zero balance achieved at 163 kg K/ha/year input.
At low application rates, mineral K (44%) showed better utilization than FYM (9%). At higher rates, no significant difference.

comparative_results.statistical_significance: All factors statistically significant (P < 0.05 or P < 0.001).
comparative_results.practical_significance: Crop factor (34%) had a dominant influence on available K contents compared to weather (3%) and field differences (3%). Unexplained factors accounted for 42% of variability.
'Two-peak' character of available K curve is common to all experimental sites, but different mean levels of available K are observed, connected to initial nutrient status and soil properties.

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265m; Humpolec: 525m; Pernolec: 530m; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 290m.
geographic_details.landscape_position: Arable soils, representing different pedo- and climasequences.

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Not explicitly classified, but sites represent different climasequences.

temperature_patterns.average_annual_temperature: Hněvčeves: 8.1°C; Humpolec: 6.6°C; Pernolec: 7.1°C; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 8.1°C.

precipitation_patterns.average_annual_precipitation: Hněvčeves: 597mm; Humpolec: 667mm; Pernolec: 559mm; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 696mm.

climate_characteristics.growing_season: Not explicitly defined, but crop rotation includes various crops with different growing seasons.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Haplic Cambisol; Pernolec: Cambisol; Kostelec n. Orlicí: Haplic Luvisol.
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: loam; Humpolec: sandy loam; Pernolec: sandy loam-loam; Kostelec n. Orlicí: sandy loam.
soil_properties.organic_matter: Hněvčeves: 1.0% C_ox; Humpolec: 1.7% C_ox; Pernolec: 1.1% C_ox; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 1.1% C_ox (initial values).

chemical_properties.pH_kcl: Hněvčeves: 6.4; Humpolec: 6.1; Pernolec: 6.0; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 6.3 (initial values).
chemical_properties.available_p_egner: Hněvčeves: 73 mg/kg; Humpolec: 27 mg/kg; Pernolec: 71 mg/kg; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 62 mg/kg (initial values).
chemical_properties.available_k_schachschabel: Hněvčeves: 119 mg/kg; Humpolec: 212 mg/kg; Pernolec: 185 mg/kg; Kostelec n. Orlicí: 119 mg/kg (initial values).

soil_properties.mineralogy: Parent material: Hněvčeves: loess; Humpolec: paragneiss; Pernolec: orthogneiss; Kostelec n. Orlicí: loess.

cropping_systems: 8-year crop rotation: 50% cereals (winter wheat, spring barley), potato/sugar beet, silage maize, clover/alfalfa.
land_use_context.management_intensity: Varies by treatment, from zero input to excess nutrient application rates, reflecting standard agricultural practice and higher/lower intensities.
land_use_context.historical_context: Long-term experiments established in 1980, with some trials dating back to 1955. Changes in agronomic sector after 1989 led to dramatic drop in K mineral fertilizer use (from pre-1989 levels to 8 kg/ha mineral K and 17 kg K in manures annually by 2007).
sustainability_metrics: Soil available nutrient levels (K, P, Ca, Mg, organic carbon, total N, pH)

yield_levels.general_observations: High yields of sugar beet can compensate for high K input. Lack of K limited alfalfa yields in some treatments.

types: Nitrogen (N) as ammonium nitrate or ammonium sulphate
timing: N: before sowing and during vegetation
FYM: twice during a rotation cycle (for sugar beet and silage maize)
K fertilizer: before sowing of alfalfa and oat (not during alfalfa stand)
Liming: each second year, after 1995 only if necessary to reach neutral soil reaction.

other_practices.tillage: Ploughing (mentioned as a source of variability due to subsoil incorporation).

balance_calculations.k_balance_method: Difference between K input (farmyard manure and mineral K) and K output by harvested plant material. K leaching and atmospheric deposition were not taken into account.
balance_calculations.k_balance_range_common_practice: -75 to -185 kg K/ha/year (at low/zero K inputs, from Macháček et al. 2001)
balance_calculations.k_balance_zero_slope_level: -78 kg K/ha/year (balance for stabilized available K level)

data_collection_schedule: Annually after harvest for soil and plant samples (initially)
Reduced sampling after 1989, with non-regular sampling for some treatments (e.g., 1988, 1995, 2007)
Regular sampling (1-2 year periodicity) for combinations A, B, C, E, I, J.
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annual (initially), then irregular for some treatments.

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Periodic fluctuations within the 8-year crop rotation cycle, showing a 'two-peak' character.
peak_periods: After silage maize (4th year of rotation)
After sugar beet (7th year of rotation)

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Varies by treatment, from slight decrease to significant increase.
long_term_trends.projection_timeframe: Not explicitly projected, but implications for future K management are discussed.
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Current agricultural practices often lead to negative K balances, relying on mobilization of internal soil K sources. Long-term sustainability requires increased K application rates (e.g., to 170 kg K/ha/year to stabilize available K).

inter_annual_variability.available_k_range_crop_rotation: 88 to 149 mg K/kg (± 26% of the mean)
inter_annual_variability.available_k_range_long_term_trends: Interannual increases caused by long-term trends are of much lower extent (order of magnitude lower) than K variability caused by crops.

spatial_variability.field_differences_influence: Low significance (3% of total variability) on available K contents, but different mean levels of available K observed across sites.

measurement_uncertainty.residual_variability: High (42% of total variability) pointing to other unknown factors (e.g., soil, sampling, analytical variability).
measurement_uncertainty.reported_variability_other_studies: Differences between successive sampling dates sometimes larger than differences between treatments (Jouany et al. 1996); graduation of double-lactate K in individual years existed on different levels (± 20 mg K/kg) (Merbach and Deubel 2007).

drivers_of_variability: Growing of different crops (dominant influence, 34% of variability)
Interannual weather fluctuations (low significance, 3% of variability)
Differences among experimental fields (low significance, 3% of variability)
Accidental incorporation of subsoil into plough layer during ploughing
Water content at sampling and drying, and subsequent release or fixation of K
Side transfer of more fertilized soil from adjacent plots (due to insufficient agrotechnics)

methodological_strengths: Long-term nature of the experiment allows separation of manipulation effects from other variables and evaluation of long-term fertilization impacts.
Polyfactorial design allows investigation of multiple independent factors.
Sufficient replication for the medium K treatment (10 replications) for statistical evaluation of variability.
Comprehensive data collection including soil and plant analysis for multiple nutrients.
methodological_limitations: Consistency of experiments disturbed by financial issues after 1989 (termination of 4 sites, changes in crop rotation, reduction of soil sampling).
Analytical method for available K changed during the study, requiring data transformation (though equations were derived from large datasets).
K balance calculations did not account for K leaching or atmospheric deposition.
K balance covers the whole soil profile, but only plough layer K was analyzed, making direct comparison of K balance with plough layer K changes not fully correct.
Experimental design has limited possibilities to evaluate influences beyond defined factors.
High residual unexplained variability (42%) suggests unquantified factors influencing available K data.
Potential for accidental incorporation of subsoil into plough layer during ploughing.
Potential for side transfer of fertilized soil from adjacent plots (due to insufficient agrotechnics).
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: Good for the main site (Hněvčeves) and medium K treatment. Less complete for other sites and treatments due to sampling reductions.

measurement_precision.available_k_variability: High variability observed, with between-year differences sometimes larger than between-treatment differences. Residual variability of 42% indicates significant unexplained measurement or inherent soil variability.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Good for Czech Republic arable soils, as sites represent different pedo- and climasequences. However, main focus is on Hněvčeves.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Long-term data (since 1980) provides good temporal coverage, but irregular sampling for some treatments limits direct trend analysis without adjustment.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Crop rotation used in the trial is described as 'probably more K-demanding than others', which might limit generalizability to all agricultural systems.

uncertainty_sources: Sampling variability (e.g., water content at sampling, accidental subsoil incorporation)
Unaccounted K losses (leaching) and inputs (atmospheric deposition) in K balance calculations.
Changes in crop rotation and sampling frequency over time.
validation_evidence: K balance calculations compared with data from other fertilization experiments (Macháček et al. 2001).
K transformation equations validated against data from Central Institute for Supervising and Testing in Agriculture (Trávník 2008).

key_methodological_references: Cochran W.G., Cox G.M. (1957): Experimental Designs.
Hraško J. et al. (1962): Soil Analyses (for Schachtschabel method).

Trávník (2008): Monitoring influence of graduating fertilization intensity on crop yields and on agrochemical soil properties. Evaluation of analytical methods for soil available nutrients (for Mehlich II/III transformation).
comparative_studies: Macháček V. et al. (2001): Potassium Fertilization in Czech Republic (for K balance ranges).
Blake L. et al. (1999): Potassium content in soil, uptake in plants and the potassium balance in three European long-term field experiments (for reduced fertilizer K effectiveness).
Witter E., Johansson G. (2001): Potassium uptake from the subsoil by green manure crops (for subsoil K uptake by forage crops).
Jouany C. et al. (1996): Long-term effects of potassium fertilization on yields and fertility status of calcareous soils of south-west France (for unexplained K variability).
Merbach W., Deubel A. (2007): The Long-Term Fertilization Trials in Halle (Saale), Germany (for unexplained K variability).
El Dessougi H. et al. (2002): Potassium efficiency mechanisms of wheat, barley, and sugar beet grown on a K fixing soil under controlled conditions (for sugar beet K uptake efficiency).
Andrist-Rangel Y. et al. (2007): Long-term K dynamics in organic and conventional mixed cropping systems as related to management and soil properties (for K deficit vs. soil K pool).
Lauringson E. et al. (2004): The effect of tillage and crop rotation on the content of available nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium (for K decrease in high K soils).
Holmqvist J. et al. (2003): Application of the PROFILE model to estimate potassium release from mineral weathering in Northern European agricultural soils (for K release from mineral weathering).
Fotyma M. (2007): Content of potassium in different forms in the soils of southeast Poland (for fixed K pool).
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Long-term trials are essential for examining cultivation-based changes in agro-ecosystems and evaluating effects of long-term fertilization intensity on nutrient dynamics. K balance is a key concept. K mobilization from internal soil sources (weathering of minerals, release of fixed K) is crucial for sustainable K management under negative K balances.
data_sources: Central Institute for Supervising and Testing in Agriculture (CISTA) for K transformation equations.
benchmarking_data: K balance ranges from common agricultural practice (Macháček et al. 2001).
K variability data from other long-term experiments (Jouany et al. 1996, Merbach and Deubel 2007).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in methodological details, quantitative findings for K dynamics and balance, and discussion of influencing factors and limitations. Specific instrumentation, precise coordinates, and detailed yield data are not provided.
potential_ambiguities: Exact coordinates for study sites are not provided.
Specific instrumentation used for analyses is not detailed.
Yield levels are mentioned qualitatively but not quantitatively.
The term 'seasonal' is used for crop rotation cycle fluctuations, which is more inter-annual than seasonal in the strict sense.
extraction_limitations: Inability to extract precise GPS coordinates.
Lack of specific yield data for crops.
Limited detail on quality control procedures beyond method transformation.
recommended_validation_checks: Cross-reference K balance calculations with reported inputs/outputs if full data tables were available.
Verify the K transformation equations if original data were accessible.

corrections_applied: Removed incorrect 'Careful agrotechnics' entry from 'quality_control' as it was a misinterpretation of a limitation.
Rephrased the description of non-regular sampling years in 'monitoring_timeline' for improved precision regarding their correspondence to crop rotation years.
enhancements_added: Added specific ANOVA statistics (SS, df, F, P-values) to the 'measurement_context' for 'Available K variability explained by factors' to provide more complete quantitative detail.
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Corrections address misinterpretations of the original text, ensuring higher accuracy. Enhancements provide more granular quantitative data, improving the richness and utility of the extraction for scientific analysis.

validation_quality.validator_notes: The initial extraction was of high quality. The validation process identified a key misinterpretation regarding 'agrotechnics' in quality control and a minor imprecision in temporal context description. Quantitative data was enriched with specific statistical values. The enhanced extraction is now more accurate and detailed.

results.paper_id: Interannual dynamics of available potassium in a long-term fertilization experiment
